If primary PCI cannot be performed within 120 minutes, thrombolytic therapy (e.g., tenecteplase) should be administered, barring any contraindications. After successful thrombolysis, expeditious transfer to a PCI-capable facility should be part of a pharmacoinvasive strategy because of the potential for coronary reocclusion. Transfer is also warranted for rescue PCI when reperfusion is not successful.

Key learning point: In addition to aspirin and heparin, the type of medication that should typically be administered to a patient with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction who is facing more than a 2-hour delay before percutaneous coronary intervention is a thrombolytic drug, such as tenecteplase.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with an adenosine diphosphate-receptor antagonist (prasugrel or ticagrelor) or a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., eptifibatide or tirofiban) is used in patients with STEMI who undergo primary PCI. However, these medications are not as effective as a thrombolytic agent when administered as primary reperfusion therapy; in addition, when combined with thrombolytic agents, they do not improve mortality but increase the risk of bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with an adenosine diphosphate-receptor antagonist (prasugrel or ticagrelor) or a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., eptifibatide or tirofiban) is used in patients with STEMI who undergo primary PCI. However, these medications are not as effective as a thrombolytic agent when administered as primary reperfusion therapy; in addition, when combined with thrombolytic agents, they do not improve mortality but increase the risk of bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with an adenosine diphosphate-receptor antagonist (prasugrel or ticagrelor) or a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., eptifibatide or tirofiban) is used in patients with STEMI who undergo primary PCI. However, these medications are not as effective as a thrombolytic agent when administered as primary reperfusion therapy; in addition, when combined with thrombolytic agents, they do not improve mortality but increase the risk of bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with an adenosine diphosphate-receptor antagonist (prasugrel or ticagrelor) or a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., eptifibatide or tirofiban) is used in patients with STEMI who undergo primary PCI. However, these medications are not as effective as a thrombolytic agent when administered as primary reperfusion therapy; in addition, when combined with thrombolytic agents, they do not improve mortality but increase the risk of bleeding.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman reports a one-hour history of acute-onset anterior chest pressure associated with shortness of breath.
She has a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 145/78 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 89% while breathing ambient air. Inspiratory crackles extend more than halfway up both lung fields. She has no murmurs, but a third heart sound (S3 gallop) is audible. Her extremities are warm.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
In addition to aspirin and oxygen, which one of the following combinations of medications should be administered immediately to this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility.

B) CORRECT:

Given that an anterior myocardial infarction is not typically associated with right ventricular involvement, nitroglycerin use is appropriate. Morphine is the drug of choice for pain relief in patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, especially those whose course is complicated by heart failure or pulmonary edema as noted in this case. This drug can alleviate the work of breathing, reduce anxiety, and favorably affect ventricular loading conditions.

Key learning point: The two medication classes that should be avoided in a patient with decompensated heart failure and an acute myocardial infarction are beta-blockers and calcium-channel blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility. Beta-blockers are also contraindicated in patients who have an acute myocardial infarction with advanced (second- or third-degree) atrioventricular block.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility. Beta-blockers are also contraindicated in patients who have an acute myocardial infarction with advanced (second- or third-degree) atrioventricular block.

E) INCORRECT:

An angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, such as lisinopril, is appropriate in this patient with an anterior myocardial infarction, but not in combination with a beta-blocker. Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and remote ischemic stroke is hospitalized after an episode of chest discomfort that awoke him from sleep. On the way to the hospital, he was given aspirin 325 mg orally and two sublingual nitroglycerin tablets, which resolved the discomfort.
An electrocardiogram done in the emergency department was normal, and the patient’s physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing reveals a creatine-kinase MB level of 10 ng/mL (reference range, 0–7) and a troponin-T level (measured using a 4th-generation assay) of 1.8 ng/mL (0–0.03).
Which one of the following approaches to antiplatelet therapy is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Oral clopidogrel 75 mg daily without a loading dose
A 60-mg loading dose of oral prasugrel, then a maintenance dose of 10 mg daily
A 300- or 600-mg loading dose of oral clopidogrel, then a maintenance dose of 75 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with NSTEMI should also receive a loading dose of the P2Y12 inhibitor to achieve early, adequate platelet inhibition. In patients who require coronary artery bypass surgery, some experts would recommend holding P2Y12 inhibitors for 5 days before the procedure because of concern about potential intraoperative bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke because the drug confers an increased risk for intracranial bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor, such as tirofiban, before diagnostic angiography is not associated with reduced risk for cardiovascular events, and it significantly increases the risk for major bleeding. Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors should generally be used after diagnostic angiography to minimize bleeding complications. In very high-risk patients, such as those with markedly elevated troponin levels and dynamic electrocardiographic changes, early addition of a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (i.e., before angiography) may be indicated.

D) CORRECT:

All patients with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor), because outcomes in both conservative and invasive treatment strategies are better with dual therapy than with aspirin alone. Patients with NSTEMI should also receive a loading dose of the P2Y12 inhibitor to achieve early, adequate platelet inhibition. In patients who require coronary artery bypass surgery, some experts would recommend holding P2Y12 inhibitors for 5 days before the procedure because of concern about potential intraoperative bleeding,

Key learning point: A patient with a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction should receive antiplatelet therapy involving aspirin and clopidogrel or another P2Y12 inhibitor.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin should be continued but is not sufficient without an adjunctive P2Y12 inhibitor.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia reports 2 days of intermittent chest discomfort at rest. Her initial heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia with 1-mm lateral ST-segment depressions during an episode of chest pain, which resolves with sublingual nitroglycerin. Antiplatelet and antithrombotic therapy is initiated.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme (ng/mL)
13
0–7


Total creatine kinase (U/liter)
200
40–150


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
2.0
0–0.03


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Her GRACE 2.0 risk score is 155, and her TIMI score is 5.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate coronary angiography and intervention (within 2 hours after first medical contact)
Continued antiplatelet and antithrombotic therapy for 48 hours, followed by coronary angiography within 3 to 5 days
Early coronary angiography and intervention (within 12 to 24 hours)
Delayed coronary angiography (after 24 hours but within 72 hours)
Continued antiplatelet and antithrombotic therapy without coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The urgent revascularization approach is indicated for patients with NSTEMI and a “very high” mortality risk, whereas this patient's risk is “high”. See “Risk-dependent timing of revascularization in NSTE-ACS” table.

B) INCORRECT:

This is not a recommended approach for any of the NSTEMI mortality risk groups. See “Risk-dependent timing of revascularization in NSTE-ACS” table.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Furthermore, she has several risk factors for experiencing a poor outcome from her NSTEMI, including advanced age, multiple conditions associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, recurrent episodes of chest pain, tachycardia and low blood pressure on admission, ST-segment depression on electrocardiography, and elevated cardiac biomarkers. These risk factors are components of both the GRACE score and the TIMI risk scoring system. Based on these risk-stratification tools, this patient has a high-risk NSTEMI with a >3% risk for in-hospital death. Patients with high-risk NSTEMI derive the greatest benefit from an early invasive strategy, in which coronary angiography and intervention (if appropriate) are performed within 12 to 24 hours after presentation. Clinical trials have shown that patients with high-risk NSTEMI have lower rates of death and other cardiovascular events with an early, rather than delayed, invasive strategy.

In other scenarios, coronary angiography may be more or less urgent. The “Risk-dependent timing of revascularization in NSTE-ACS” table summarizes the current guideline-supported criteria for determining the appropriate urgency of coronary angiography in patients with NSTEMI or UA. Of note, these criteria do not apply to patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction, where immediate revascularization is indicated.

Key learning point: In a patient with a high-risk non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, the timing of coronary angiography should be within 12 to 24 hours after presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

The delayed invasive approach is indicated for patients with NSTEMI and an “intermediate” mortality risk, whereas this patient's risk is “high”. See “Risk-dependent timing of revascularization in NSTE-ACS” table.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a high mortality risk NSETMI and coronary angiography is indicated. A choice against coronary angiography may be made in shared decision-making if the patient has multiple comorbidities that would make the intervention very risky or if the patient does not wish to undergo intervention.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman is transferred from a distant hospital after receiving intravenous tenecteplase, 16 hours ago, for an anterior ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction. She is now free of chest pain.
The patient’s history includes emphysema, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She currently smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily.
Her heart rate is 69 beats per minute with regular rhythm, her blood pressure is 143/85 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air. Her jugular venous pressure is estimated at 10 cm. She has fine crackles at the lung bases, no heart murmurs, and 1+ lower-extremity edema.
Her electrocardiograms before and after thrombolytic therapy are available for review (figures 1 and 2).
An echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 32%, anteroseptal and apical akinesis, and mild mitral regurgitation.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatine kinase (U/liter)
842
40–150


Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme (ng/mL)
105
0–7


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
68.5
0–0.03


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
692
≤91


Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Exercise nuclear stress test within several weeks
Persantine nuclear stress test within several days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography and nuclear perfusion testing are noninvasive imaging tests that should not replace early invasive assessment by cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography and nuclear perfusion testing are noninvasive imaging tests that should not replace early invasive assessment by cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography and nuclear perfusion testing are noninvasive imaging tests that should not replace early invasive assessment by cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

D) CORRECT:

Thrombolytic therapy can reduce the mortality risk associated with an ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction. It should be administered to patients who present within 12 hours after symptom onset when primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) cannot be performed within 2 hours.

Clinical markers of successful reperfusion include resolution of chest pain, >70% ST-segment resolution on electrocardiogram (ECG), and reperfusion arrhythmias, such as accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

This patient’s initial ECG shows 2 to 3 mm of ST-segment elevation in the anteroseptal leads, with occasional premature ventricular contractions. The subsequent ECG shows evidence of an evolving anterior myocardial infarction.

Urgent transfer to a PCI-capable hospital is recommended for patients who are in cardiogenic shock, have severe heart failure, or have failed reperfusion. Early cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography — within 24 hours (but not within the first 2 to 3 hours after thrombolysis) — is recommended for patients with ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction who have received thrombolytic therapy, even when they are hemodynamically stable and have clinical evidence of successful reperfusion. In a randomized trial comparing this approach with standard treatment (usually delayed angiography), early cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography was associated with lower risks for reinfarction and recurrent ischemia but not mortality.

Key learning point: Within 24 hours after successful thrombolytic therapy for an anterior ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction, management should involve an early invasive approach of cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Early cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography — within 24 hours (but not within the first 2 to 3 hours after thrombolysis) — is recommended for patients with ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction who have received thrombolytic therapy, even when they are hemodynamically stable and have clinical evidence of successful reperfusion.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department one hour after the acute onset of substernal chest pressure that radiates to his left neck. He describes the pressure as a 5 out of 10 in intensity and also reports nausea. His symptoms began while he was watching television. Emergency medical personnel treated him with morphine 2 mg intravenously and one sublingual nitroglycerin tablet, which relieved the chest pressure.
Four years ago, the patient underwent three-vessel coronary bypass graft surgery; during the 4 years following surgery, he had not experienced chest pain until the current episode. His medical history is also notable for ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.
In the emergency department, his heart rate is 95 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 165/86 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 9 cm. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm with no audible murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation. He has 1+ lower-extremity edema.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Initial laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatine kinase (U/liter)
253
60–400


Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme (ng/mL)
4
0–7


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
<0.01
0–0.03


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
428
≤46


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Measurement of cardiac biomarkers is a key part of diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI). Troponin is the primary biomarker for MI; it appears in the blood very quickly after myocardial injury and has high sensitivity and specificity for such injury. Conventional troponin assays may be able to detect an elevation in this protein as early as 2 hours after cardiac injury; however, these assays are not sensitive enough to detect small increases in troponin and so may not be able to detect an elevation for up to 12 hours. Newer, high-sensitivity (5th-generation) troponin assays are able to detect cardiac injury sooner, even within the first 2 hours after the event. Given the difference in these assays, clinicians should be sure to know the performance of the particular assay used at their own institution.

Serum creatine kinase (CK) and its MB isoenzyme (CK-MB) is an alternative biomarker for detecting myocardial injury. However, it is less sensitive than troponin, as CK-MB levels do not typically rise until 4 to 6 hours after the onset of infarction.

Although elevations in brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are associated with heart failure, they can also occur with acute coronary syndromes, and significant elevations are associated with worse outcomes. This transient ischemia seems to increase cardiac-wall stress and induce BNP synthesis and release in proportion to the degree of ischemia.

In this case, the patient has known coronary disease and underwent a conventional troponin assay within 2 hours after the onset of chest pain at rest that was possibly ischemic. Thus, despite his normal troponin and CK-MB levels, the most likely diagnosis is acute coronary syndrome — a term that includes both unstable angina and MI. The electrocardiogram in this case demonstrates sinus rhythm with minor nonspecific changes and poor R-wave progression.

Key learning point: On conventional assays, serum troponin levels do not become detectable until at least 2 hours after myonecrosis. Newer assays allow for earlier detection.

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism is typically associated with dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Costochondritis refers to musculoskeletal chest-wall pain that is reproducible with palpation; it generally does not radiate to the neck, and it often increases with a deep breath or change in body position.

D) INCORRECT:

Heart failure exacerbations usually manifest with dyspnea and are not typically associated with acute onset of chest pain. Although elevations in brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are associated with heart failure, they can also occur with acute coronary syndromes, and significant elevations are associated with worse outcomes. This transient ischemia seems to increase cardiac-wall stress and induce BNP synthesis and release in proportion to the degree of ischemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Stable angina pectoris is typically predictable and fairly brief (i.e., occurring at a given level of exertion and promptly resolving with rest). In contrast, this patient’s episode of chest pain was unexpected and occurred while he was at rest.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit with hypotension and an altered mental state. She has a history of coronary artery disease, right coronary artery stent placement, and a permanent pacemaker for sick sinus syndrome.
She is intubated, her heart rate is 59 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is performed (figure).
Serum concentrations of point-of-care cardiac biomarkers are elevated, and a bedside echocardiogram reveals hypokinesis of the anterior and anteroseptal walls, without pericardial effusion or valvular abnormalities.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Electrocardiography while the pacemaker is temporarily suspended
CT angiography of the thoracic aorta
An increase in the ventricular pacing rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous metoprolol could further depress left ventricular systolic function and worsen the patient’s shock.

B) CORRECT:

Detecting myocardial ischemia in a patient who has a paced rhythm or left bundle-branch block can be challenging but is not impossible. When assessing for electrocardiographic evidence of myocardial ischemia in these patients, clinicians should remember that the QRS complex and the ST-segment and T waves are usually discordant. In other words, if the QRS complex is primarily positively deflected (deflected upwards), the expected deflection of the ST-segment is downwards. However, if the observed ST-segment deflection is instead concordant with the QRS complex (i.e., in the same direction), then myocardial ischemia should be suspected. Similarly, excessive discordant ST-segment elevation may indicate myocardial ischemia.

This concept is further defined in the modified Sgarbossa criteria, which are 80% to 90% sensitive and 90% to 99% specific for acute coronary occlusion in patients with a left bundle-branch block; these test characteristics may be lower in patients with a ventricular paced rhythm. According to the modified Sgarbossa criteria, myocardial ischemia should be suspected in any patient who has left bundle-branch block or ventricular paced rhythm and:

• ≥1 lead with ≥1 mm of concordant ST-segment elevation or
• ≥1 lead of V1 to V3 with ≥1 mm of concordant ST-segment depression or
• ≥1 lead anywhere with ≥1 mm ST-segment elevation and proportionally excessive discordant ST-segment elevation, as defined by ≥25% of the depth of the preceding S wave

This patient’s electrocardiogram shows a ventricular paced rhythm with ST-segment depression ≥1 mm that is concordant with the QRS complex in multiple leads, including in the precordial leads V1–V3, which is consistent with the second criterion above and highly suspicious of myocardial ischemia. Given that this patient has findings of myocardial ischemia and is in shock, she should proceed to emergency cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography and possible revascularization.

Key learning point: In a patient with a ventricular paced rhythm, ischemia can be diagnosed if ST-segment depression ≥1 mm is present and is concordant with the QRS complex.

C) INCORRECT:

Pacemaker reprogramming can be used to examine “native” QRS morphology if the original electrocardiogram is nondiagnostic. However, the electrocardiographic findings in this patient are sufficient to be diagnostic.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the thoracic aorta could be considered to exclude aortic dissection, but that approach would delay potentially life-saving coronary revascularization.

E) INCORRECT:

The primary reason for the patient’s hypotension and shock is decreased left ventricular systolic performance related to ischemia. Increasing the ventricular pacing rate would increase myocardial oxygen demands and should, therefore, not be undertaken without revascularization.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, and obesity is scheduled to undergo a total right-knee arthroplasty in 2 weeks. His medical history is significant for a drug-eluting stent placed in his distal right coronary artery 3 years ago. His current medications are low-dose aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril.
How should this patient’s antiplatelet therapy be managed preoperatively?

choices.text: Discontinue both the aspirin and the clopidogrel permanently
Continue the aspirin through surgery and discontinue the clopidogrel permanently
Discontinue the aspirin permanently and continue the clopidogrel indefinitely
Continue the aspirin through surgery and replace the clopidogrel with an eptifibatide bridge for 5 days before surgery
Continue both the aspirin and the clopidogrel through surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is recommended for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events and should therefore be continued in this patient on a long-term basis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient received a drug-eluting stent several years ago and is currently taking low-dose aspirin and the P2Y12 inhibitor clopidogrel as antiplatelet therapy.

The recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor after implantation of a current-generation drug-eluting coronary stent depends on the original indication for the stent. If the stent implantation occurred secondary to stable angina, the recommended duration of therapy is at least 6 months. If the stent implantation occurred secondary to acute coronary syndrome, the recommended duration of therapy is one year. In this case, the patient’s stent was placed more than one year ago; thus, clopidogrel is no longer indicated. It can be discontinued permanently at this point.

Aspirin is recommended for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events and should therefore be continued in this patient on a long-term basis. Continuing aspirin therapy through surgery can be done safely in most cases except where bleeding would be very high risk (such as posterior eye surgery and neurosurgery).

Key learning point: The recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy after implantation of a drug-eluting stent depends on the original indication for the stent but should not exceed one year.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin, not clopidogrel, is recommended for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events and should be continued on a long-term basis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bridging with eptifibatide (a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor) has not been studied extensively in this patient population. Although one might consider stopping clopidogrel and bridging with eptifibatide if major surgery were required shortly after coronary stenting, this practice would not be appropriate in a patient who received a stent several years ago.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient’s stent was placed more than one year ago; thus, clopidogrel is no longer indicated and can be discontinued permanently at this point.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department after one hour of dull, substernal chest pain that is associated with nausea, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. Two months ago, she had an ischemic stroke with residual right hemiparesis. Her current medications are losartan and aspirin.
On physical examination, she is pale, diaphoretic, and in mild distress. Her heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Her heart rhythm is regular, and she has no murmurs or gallops. Bibasilar crackles are evident. Her extremities are warm and without edema.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
The hospital does not have a cardiac catheterization laboratory.
In addition to aspirin, heparin, and initiation of transfer to a facility with a cardiac catheterization laboratory, which one of the following medication regimens is appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase.

B) CORRECT:

The ultimate goal for a patient with an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is timely reperfusion of the infarct-related artery pharmacologically (i.e., with thrombolytic therapy) or mechanically (i.e., with percutaneous coronary intervention [PCI]).

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase. Other absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy include previous intracranial hemorrhage, cerebrovascular lesion or intracranial neoplasm, suspected aortic dissection, active bleeding or diatheses, closed-head or facial trauma within the past 3 months, intracranial or intraspinal surgery within the past 2 months, and severe uncontrolled hypertension that is unresponsive to emergency treatment.

Given that this patient is not a candidate for thrombolytic therapy, she should be referred for primary PCI. The hospital does not have the capability to perform PCI, so she should be transferred expeditiously to a facility that can perform the procedure. The goal is to perform primary PCI within 90 minutes after the first medical contact.

Key learning point: An ischemic stroke in the 3 months prior to an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase.

D) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase.

E) INCORRECT:

All STEMI patients referred for primary PCI should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin plus clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor. For this particular patient, who has a history of stroke, clopidogrel or ticagrelor is preferred over prasugrel. Use of prasugrel should be avoided in patients with a previous stroke or transient ischemic attack, those aged >75 years, and those with body weight <60 kg, because these groups have the highest risk for prasugrel-associated bleeding complications.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is hospitalized with an acute coronary syndrome. She is initially treated with aspirin, prasugrel, metoprolol, and heparin. Twelve hours after admission, she is free of pain.
She has the following fasting lipid concentrations: total cholesterol 202 mg/dL (reference range, 125–200), LDL cholesterol 110 mg/dL (<130), and triglycerides 120 mg/dL (<150).
Which one of the following lipid-lowering therapies, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regardless of the patient's initial cholesterol values, statin therapy is considered a standard part of treatment for acute coronary syndrome patients during the index hospitalization. High-intensity atorvastatin (80 mg daily), compared with the other lipid-lowering regimen options presented, has been shown to limit the incidence of recurrent ischemia and revascularization in such patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Regardless of the patient's initial cholesterol values, statin therapy is considered a standard part of treatment for acute coronary syndrome patients during the index hospitalization. High-intensity atorvastatin (80 mg daily), compared with the other lipid-lowering regimen options presented, has been shown to limit the incidence of recurrent ischemia and revascularization in such patients.

C) CORRECT:

Regardless of the patient's initial cholesterol values, statin therapy is considered a standard part of treatment for acute coronary syndrome patients during the index hospitalization. High-intensity atorvastatin (80 mg daily), compared with the other lipid-lowering regimen options presented, has been shown to limit the incidence of recurrent ischemia and revascularization in such patients.

Key learning point: The lipid-lowering therapy that is most appropriate for a patient with an acute coronary syndrome is high-dose statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg daily.

D) INCORRECT:

Regardless of the patient's initial cholesterol values, statin therapy is considered a standard part of treatment for acute coronary syndrome patients during the index hospitalization. High-intensity atorvastatin (80 mg daily), compared with the other lipid-lowering regimen options presented, has been shown to limit the incidence of recurrent ischemia and revascularization in such patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Regardless of the patient's initial cholesterol values, statin therapy is considered a standard part of treatment for acute coronary syndrome patients during the index hospitalization. High-intensity atorvastatin (80 mg daily), compared with the other lipid-lowering regimen options presented, has been shown to limit the incidence of recurrent ischemia and revascularization in such patients.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 3 hours of left substernal chest pain that radiates to his neck. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and stage 2 chronic kidney disease. He has smoked cigarettes for 25 years.
On examination, he is in mild distress. His heart rate is regular at 105 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 90% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is measured at 12 cm. He has a 2/6 mid-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur radiating to the carotids, as well as normal first and second heart sounds. He has bilateral basilar rales and no lower-extremity edema.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Subendocardial ischemia secondary to oxygen supply-demand mismatch

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic stenosis would be likely to cause a late-peaking murmur that radiates to the patient’s cervical area, as well as a diminished second heart sound. Aortic stenosis commonly causes left ventricular hypertrophy, which this patient does not have. The murmur presented in this case is a functional murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute pulmonary embolism can be associated with nonspecific ST-T abnormalities, sinus tachycardia, axis deviation, bundle-branch block and other electrocardiographic, including evidence of right heart strain, but not changes in one vascular territory that are more indicative of myocardial ischemia and infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy (thickening of the myocardium of the left ventricle) may be identified by increased voltage on an electrocardiogram. Several sets of electrocardiographic diagnostic criteria exist for this condition, but none is ideal. The patient’s electrocardiographic findings do not meet criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy (i.e., QRS voltage is not increased) with strain. For example, the sum of S in V1 and R in V5 and V6 is <35 mm, and the R in aVL is <11 mm.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis is associated with diffuse PR-segment depression and diffuse ST-segment elevation and subsequent T-wave abnormalities (rather than ST-segment elevation isolated to a vascular territory, as in this case).

E) CORRECT:

ST-segment elevation that is more prominent in lead aVR than in lead V1 indicates that there is likely subendocardial ischemia due to an oxygen supply-demand mismatch. This mismatch may be secondary to an obstruction of the left main coronary artery, a proximal left anterior descending coronary artery stenosis, severe three-vessel coronary artery disease, hypoxemia, or hypotension. This high-risk scenario requires triage to a center that can perform urgent intervention if necessary.

Key learning point: ST-segment elevation in lead aVR in a patient with acute coronary syndrome indicates diffuse subendocardial ischemia.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and well-controlled type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of upper abdominal discomfort. The discomfort, which she describes as a gnawing sensation, initially occurred once or twice daily and lasted 5 to 10 minutes, but now it occurs more frequently and lasts longer. Her latest episode, which occurred while she was walking down a hallway, was accompanied by nausea, fatigue, and diaphoresis.
Her medications include metformin, aspirin, and lisinopril.
Her blood pressure is 154/89 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 98 beats per minute. An abdominal examination is unremarkable, although she reports mild discomfort that began while she was registering for the visit. Liver function test results and pancreatic enzyme levels are within normal limits.
CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast is unremarkable.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Women, older adults, and patients with diabetes mellitus are more likely than other patients to lack typical, ischemic chest pain when they experience a myocardial infarction (MI). Health care providers should remain vigilant for nonclassic symptoms of MI, such as diaphoresis, unexplained fatigue, nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal discomfort, and exertional symptoms. An MI should be excluded as a matter of urgency in this older woman with unexplained, worsening abdominal discomfort. If the presentation represents unstable angina, an electrocardiogram may show abnormalities only during an episode of pain.

Key learning point: Nonclassic presentations of angina are most common in older patients, patients with diabetes mellitus, and women.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient’s symptoms could result from a gastric or a duodenal ulcer, a serious cardiac condition such as MI should be ruled out before a barium swallow study or esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) provides images of the biliary system and associated abdominal organs. Although choledocholithiasis and cholelithiasis should certainly be considered in light of the patient’s symptoms, right-upper-quadrant ultrasonography would be a simpler test than MRCP. In addition, given the potential life-threatening nature of coronary artery disease, it is more important to evaluate first for nonclassic presentations of coronary disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient’s symptoms could result from a gastric or a duodenal ulcer, a serious cardiac condition such as MI should be ruled out before a barium swallow study or esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed.

E) INCORRECT:

D-dimer testing has high sensitivity for ruling out pulmonary embolism (PE) when the patient has a low probability of PE, but it has no diagnostic value in managing this patient, whose symptoms are not at all consistent with a PE.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents for routine follow-up. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, osteoarthritis, and coronary artery disease.
Four months ago, he was hospitalized with a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, and a drug-eluting stent was placed in the left circumflex coronary artery. He has done well since the stent placement and is exercising several times per week with no cardiac symptoms. His hypertension is well-controlled. His current medications are metoprolol, lisinopril, simvastatin, metformin, aspirin, and ticagrelor.
He is eager to stop taking ticagrelor. He has not experienced any episodes of overt bleeding and is determined not to be at high risk of bleeding.
According to current guidelines, at least how long after drug-eluting stent placement must this patient wait to permanently discontinue ticagrelor safely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It is safe to discontinue ticagrelor 6 months after placing a drug-eluting stent for stable ischemic heart disease. Since this patient does not have a high risk for bleeding and had a stent placed for acute coronary syndrome, ticagrelor must be continued for a longer duration.

B) INCORRECT:

Ticagrelor must be continued for a longer duration than 3 months in this patient who does not have a high risk of bleeding and had a stent placed for acute coronary syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

It is safe to discontinue ticagrelor earlier in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT; aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) is recommended after stent placement to reduce the risk for stent thrombosis, an acute thrombotic occlusion within the stent that often causes ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. The type of stent is a factor that influences the duration of DAPT. Late stent thrombosis (occurring > 1 month after the procedure) is more common with a drug-eluting stent (DES) than with a bare-metal stent (BMS). Other factors influencing the duration of DAPT include the reason for revascularization (acute coronary syndrome vs. stable ischemic heart disease) and the risk of bleeding.

Current (2021) guidelines from the American Heart Association (AHA) and American College of Cardiology (ACC) strongly recommend the following minimum durations of DAPT after stent placement:

• 1 month for a patient who has had a BMS placed for stable ischemic heart disease
• 6 months for a patient who has had a DES placed for stable ischemic heart disease
• 12 months for a patient who has had a stent (BMS or DES) placed for acute coronary syndrome

In patients who qualify for > 1 month of DAPT, an alternative approach (moderate recommendation) is to discontinue aspirin after 1–3 months and continue P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy. After 6 months of DAPT, the P2Y12 inhibitor can be interrupted briefly for elective surgery. If there is a high risk of bleeding, it may be reasonable (weak recommendation) to permanently discontinue the P2Y12 inhibitor 3 months after placing a DES for stable ischemic heart disease and 6 months after placing a stent for acute coronary syndrome.

In this patient who does not have a high risk of bleeding and had a stent placed for non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, ticagrelor can be safely discontinued 12 months after stent placement.

Key learning point: For a patient who has had a drug-eluting stent placed in a coronary artery for acute coronary syndrome, the recommended minimum duration of dual antiplatelet therapy before it can be permanently discontinued, according to current guidelines, is 12 months.

E) INCORRECT:

It is safe to discontinue ticagrelor 1 month after a bare-metal stent is placed for stable ischemic heart disease. Late stent thrombosis (occurring >1 month after the procedure) is more common with a drug-eluting stent than with a bare-metal stent.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man who underwent a total left-hip arthroplasty yesterday reports acute-onset chest pain that began one hour ago. His history is significant for coronary artery disease; and 3 years ago, he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent to his right coronary artery. His inpatient medications after the hip procedure are aspirin, metoprolol tartrate, rosuvastatin, lisinopril, and tamsulosin, as well as hydromorphone as needed.
His heart rate is 92 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% on 4 liters of supplemental oxygen. He has a regular rate and rhythm, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, and a short systolic murmur over the left sternal border.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous heparin and CT of the chest according to a pulmonary embolism protocol
Immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography
Metoprolol, heparin, and nitroglycerin — followed by observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may be at increased risk for postoperative pulmonary embolism or acute heart failure, his electrocardiogram findings are diagnostic for myocardial ischemia. Therefore, urgent echocardiography or a pulmonary embolism protocol chest CT scan would not be indicated for this patient. Delays from unnecessary testing may be associated with increased mortality.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads (II, III and aVF) with 2 mm of elevation above the baseline. There is also associated ST depression in leads V2–V4, which are consistent with reciprocal changes. A perioperative ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is a medical emergency that may signal in-stent thrombosis in a patient who has a history of coronary stenting. Urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is an appropriate diagnostic and potentially therapeutic procedure in a perioperative patient with electrocardiographic evidence of STEMI and symptoms of less than 12 hours.

Key learning point: Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction identified in the perioperative setting warrants urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, heparin, and nitroglycerin should be considered for a patient with an acute coronary syndrome but should not delay definitive management of the STEMI with coronary angiography. In addition, in the setting of an inferior myocardial infarction, one should first exclude right ventricular involvement before initiating nitroglycerin.

D) INCORRECT:

Tirofiban and heparin may be appropriate in some patients who are undergoing coronary stenting but are not immediately indicated before urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may be at increased risk for postoperative pulmonary embolism or acute heart failure, his electrocardiogram findings are diagnostic for myocardial ischemia. The electrocardiographic findings of acute pericarditis would be more diffuse than the ST-T abnormalities seen here along a specific vascular territory. Therefore, urgent echocardiography or a pulmonary embolism protocol chest CT scan would not be indicated for this patient. Delays from unnecessary testing may be associated with increased mortality.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for 4 hours of anterior chest discomfort that developed after he was moving furniture and then resolved. He describes the pain as a pressure in the front of his chest, with radiation to the left shoulder.
He began intermittent hemodialysis 6 months ago for end-stage kidney disease attributed to hypertensive nephrosclerosis. He notes lower-extremity edema that resolves after dialysis but is otherwise asymptomatic. He has had hypertension for more than 30 years and also has hyperlipidemia. His current medications are aspirin, metoprolol, simvastatin, losartan, calcium acetate, and erythropoietin.
On examination, his blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. At rest, he appears to be comfortable and without pain. The pain is reproduced when he rotates his body and upon palpation of his anterior chest on the left side. He has a normal cardiac examination and clear lung fields. Bilateral trace edema is present.
An electrocardiogram indicates left ventricular hypertrophy with repolarization abnormality, consistent with previous electrocardiographic results.
Laboratory testing, conducted before dialysis, reveals a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a potassium level of 5.0 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0). A cardiac troponin-T level, obtained in the emergency department upon arrival using a 4th-generation assay, is 0.2 ng/mL (0–0.03).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Await a second cardiac troponin-T level for comparison at 4 hours after presentation
Discharge home with outpatient follow-up scheduled within 3 days
Add ticagrelor to the current regimen
Refer for immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the general population, an elevated serum cardiac troponin-T (cTnT) level is an indicator of subclinical myonecrosis and a predictor of cardiovascular and all-cause mortality independent of other cardiovascular risk factors. In patients with end-stage kidney disease, however, this marker has variable specificity: these patients often have elevated cTnT levels but no clinical evidence of acute myocardial injury. In this particular case, the patient has end-stage kidney disease and is reporting chest pain that requires further evaluation. Although no changes are seen on electrocardiogram, there is concern for cardiac ischemia given the patient's end-stage kidney disease (a known risk for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality), his reported chest pain, and his mild cTnT elevation. The most appropriate next step for this patient is to repeat the cTnT level. If the second cTnT level is higher than the first, the cause is likely cardiac, and management should be focused accordingly. If there is no change in the cTnT level, the elevation is likely due to end-stage kidney disease, and the patient's medical therapy can be continued without modification.

Key learning point: In a patient with end-stage kidney disease who undergoes intermittent dialysis, an elevated serum cardiac troponin-T level is associated with increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge home with outpatient follow-up would be reasonable if the patient’s symptoms resolved and a second cardiac troponin-T level was unchanged, but it would be premature at this point given that an acute cardiac syndrome has not been adequately ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress testing is not indicated at this time until there is determination of a follow-up cardiac troponin-T level.

D) INCORRECT:

Ticagrelor is unlikely to lower the serum cardiac troponin-T level or to reduce the risk for cardiovascular mortality on dialysis.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, as the electrocardiogram does not demonstrate ST-segment elevation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department (ED) reporting 3 hours of chest pain. He describes the pain as central, nonradiating, and alternating between sharp and aching. He first noticed it when he sat up in bed this morning, and it worsens when he gets up to walk around. He has never had such pain before and reports feeling short of breath when he tries to breathe in deeply. He does not report nausea, diaphoresis, or light-headedness. Before coming to the ED, he took four tablets of low-dose aspirin, which he believes improved his pain from 8/10 in intensity to 5/10.
He recalls having a self-limited upper respiratory tract infection one week ago but has otherwise been healthy. His family history is significant for a myocardial infarction in his father at age 62. He has never smoked and consumes minimal alcohol. His only medication is losartan 25 mg daily, and he reports that his blood pressure is well controlled.
On physical examination, he has a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 134/88 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing ambient air. Palpation of the chest wall does not reproduce the pain. His lungs are clear, and there are no cardiac murmurs or rubs.
A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm with no ST-segment changes. A high-sensitivity cardiac troponin-T level, measured using a 5th-generation assay, is 38 ng/liter at presentation and 40 ng/liter after one hour (reference range, <14).
The patient reports that his chest pain is now at 2/10 after receiving oxycodone 5 mg.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Discharge with a plan to obtain an exercise nuclear stress test as an outpatient
Discharge with an expedited referral to an outpatient cardiology clinic
Discharge from the emergency department with routine follow-up with primary care
Admit for management of acute coronary syndrome, and proceed with coronary angiography within 24 hours
Admit to a chest-pain observation unit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharging the patient for outpatient exercise nuclear stress testing (without inpatient observation) would be appropriate if the patient had no evidence of myocardial injury on troponin testing and had symptoms suggestive of stable angina or anginal equivalents, but this is not the case.

B) INCORRECT:

Although outpatient cardiology referral might ultimately be warranted for this patient, he has no known cardiac history and no other comorbidities that could explain his troponin elevation and acute myocardial injury. Therefore, referral alone (without further observation or testing in the ED) is not appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Although discharge from the ED with outpatient follow-up (and no inpatient observation) may be reasonable in the appropriate clinical context for patients with known or expected causes of chronic myocardial injury (such as stable coronary artery disease [CAD] or heart failure), this patient has no reported history of these conditions and has a CAD risk factor (hypertension). Therefore, inpatient observation and consideration of further testing is the best next step.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither this patient’s presentation nor his troponin levels are diagnostic of ACS, so invasive angiography is not indicated at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Some of the characteristics of this patient’s chest pain suggest a cause other than ischemic heart disease; specifically, his pain is postural and varies with deep breathing, and he had a recent respiratory infection, suggesting possible pericarditis or myopericarditis. Furthermore, he has had no significant change in his high-sensitivity cardiac troponin (hs-cTn) level during the past hour, which means that myocardial infarction has not been ruled in. However, acute coronary syndrome (ACS) has not been ruled out either: the patient has had two serial hs-cTn values that are elevated (usually defined as a value greater than the 99th percentile), indicating some degree of myocardial injury. The patient should therefore be admitted for further evaluation.

A third hs-cTn value can be obtained to provide further risk stratification, and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) may also be helpful, given the possibility of pericarditis or myocarditis. Further testing (such as stress testing or coronary CT angiography) could then be considered based on the TTE findings.

Interpreting Troponin Assays

High-sensitivity cardiac troponins are the preferred biomarker in patients presenting with chest pain. Since troponin assays were first introduced, they have become increasingly sensitive, allowing for earlier identification of cardiac injury. Although conventional troponin assays require repeat measurements 3 to 6 hours after the initial measurement, the newer high-sensitivity assays can make the determination of ACS within 1 to 3 hours and have greater diagnostic accuracy than the earlier assays.

The interpretation of hs-cTn values is highly assay-specific; in particular, the move from 4th-generation to 5th-generation assays is greatly influencing the interpretation of troponin values. The upper limit of the reference range and the definition of a significant change in the value varies by both assay and institutional validation. Given its increased sensitivity, the 5th-generation assay has also led to more-frequent detection of myocardial injury without infarction.

Currently, there are no updated U.S. guidelines on interpreting hs-cTn values. The European Society of Cardiology 0–1/h model is a validated, commonly used algorithm for stratifying risk in patients with chest pain. According to this model:

• A very high initial hs-cTn value (assay-specific, typically ≥52 ng/liter) — or a significant increase on one-hour serial assessment (typically ≥5 ng/liter) — would rule in ACS, accounting for symptomatology and electrocardiographic changes. A one-hour increase ≥10 ng/liter would further increase the specificity of this determination.
• A negative initial hs-cTn value with no significant one-hour increase (typically <5 ng/liter) would rule out ACS, again in the appropriate context.
• In scenarios that do not fit either category (as in this case), further inpatient observation is warranted, given that the elevated hs-cTn values indicate myocardial injury without ACS — and therefore elevated risk.

Key learning point: In a patient with chest pain, an initially elevated high-sensitivity cardiac troponin-T level — without a significant absolute change in the value after one hour — warrants further inpatient observation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department one hour after the acute onset of substernal chest pressure that radiates to his left neck. He describes the pressure as a 5 out of 10 in intensity and also reports nausea. His symptoms began while he was watching television. Pulse is 95/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 165/86 mm Hg. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 9 cm. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm with no audible murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation. An electrocardiogram is obtained. Laboratory studies show increased serum levels of brain natriuretic peptide; serum creatine kinase, creatine kinase MB isoenzyme, and troponin T levels are within normal limits. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Measurement of cardiac biomarkers is a key part of diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI). Troponin is the primary biomarker for MI; it appears in the blood very quickly after myocardial injury and has high sensitivity and specificity for such injury. Conventional troponin assays may be able to detect an elevation in this protein as early as 2 hours after cardiac injury; however, these assays are not sensitive enough to detect small increases in troponin and so may not be able to detect an elevation for up to 12 hours. Newer, high-sensitivity (5th-generation) troponin assays are able to detect cardiac injury sooner, even within the first 2 hours after the event. Given the difference in these assays, clinicians should be sure to know the performance of the particular assay used at their own institution.

Serum creatine kinase (CK) and its MB isoenzyme (CK-MB) is an alternative biomarker for detecting myocardial injury. However, it is less sensitive than troponin, as CK-MB levels do not typically rise until 4 to 6 hours after the onset of infarction.

Although elevations in brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are associated with heart failure, they can also occur with acute coronary syndromes, and significant elevations are associated with worse outcomes. This transient ischemia seems to increase cardiac-wall stress and induce BNP synthesis and release in proportion to the degree of ischemia.

In this case, the patient has known coronary disease and underwent a conventional troponin assay within 2 hours after the onset of chest pain at rest that was possibly ischemic. Thus, despite his normal troponin and CK-MB levels, the most likely diagnosis is acute coronary syndrome — a term that includes both unstable angina and MI. The electrocardiogram in this case demonstrates sinus rhythm with minor nonspecific changes and poor R-wave progression.

Key learning point: On conventional assays, serum troponin levels do not become detectable until at least 2 hours after myonecrosis. Newer assays allow for earlier detection.

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism is typically associated with dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Stable angina pectoris is typically predictable and fairly brief (i.e., occurring at a given level of exertion and promptly resolving with rest). In contrast, this patient’s episode of chest pain was unexpected and occurred while he was at rest.

D) INCORRECT:

Heart failure exacerbations usually manifest with dyspnea and are not typically associated with acute onset of chest pain. Although elevations in brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are associated with heart failure, they can also occur with acute coronary syndromes, and significant elevations are associated with worse outcomes. This transient ischemia seems to increase cardiac-wall stress and induce BNP synthesis and release in proportion to the degree of ischemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Costochondritis refers to musculoskeletal chest-wall pain that is reproducible with palpation; it generally does not radiate to the neck, and it often increases with a deep breath or change in body position.
questions.hint: This patient would benefit from dual antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and well-controlled type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of upper abdominal discomfort. She describes a gnawing sensation that initially occurred once or twice daily and lasted 5–10 minutes, but has become more frequent and prolonged. Her latest episode, which occurred while she was walking down a hallway, was accompanied by nausea, fatigue, and diaphoresis. Her medications include metformin, aspirin, and lisinopril. Her blood pressure is 154/89 mm Hg, pulse is 98/minute. Abdominal examination is unremarkable, and liver function test results and pancreatic enzyme levels are within normal limits. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast is unremarkable. Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Women, older adults, and patients with diabetes mellitus are more likely than other patients to lack typical, ischemic chest pain when they experience a myocardial infarction (MI). Health care providers should remain vigilant for nonclassic symptoms of MI, such as diaphoresis, unexplained fatigue, nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal discomfort, and exertional symptoms. An MI should be excluded as a matter of urgency in this older woman with unexplained, worsening abdominal discomfort. If the presentation represents unstable angina, an electrocardiogram may show abnormalities only during an episode of pain.

Key learning point: Nonclassic presentations of angina are most common in older patients, patients with diabetes mellitus, and women.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient’s symptoms could result from a gastric or a duodenal ulcer, a serious cardiac condition such as MI should be ruled out before a barium swallow study or esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) provides images of the biliary system and associated abdominal organs. Although choledocholithiasis and cholelithiasis should certainly be considered in light of the patient’s symptoms, right-upper-quadrant ultrasonography would be a simpler test than MRCP. In addition, given the potential life-threatening nature of coronary artery disease, it is more important to evaluate first for nonclassic presentations of coronary disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient’s symptoms could result from a gastric or a duodenal ulcer, a serious cardiac condition such as MI should be ruled out before a barium swallow study or esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed.

E) INCORRECT:

D-dimer testing has high sensitivity for ruling out pulmonary embolism (PE) when the patient has a low probability of PE, but it has no diagnostic value in managing this patient, whose symptoms are not at all consistent with a PE.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension reports 2 weeks of progressive dyspnea on exertion. He initially had dyspnea only with moderate exertion (e.g., climbing stairs), but he has subsequently noted dyspnea with minimal activity (e.g., showering). This morning, he experienced two 20-minute episodes of dyspnea with minimal activity. He states he has no chest pain, cough, or wheezing. His home medications are amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. His heart rate is 80 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. Bibasilar crackles are present in both lungs. The patient’s serum troponin-T level is normal. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure). Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation is not consistent with an exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is associated with diminished breath sounds and sputum production.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation and ECG evidence do not suggest acute pericarditis as the cause of his dyspnea. The ECG evidence does not include the diffuse changes commonly seen in patients with acute pericarditis, namely ST-segment elevation in all leads except aVR, which shows ST-segment depression. Early in the course, the PR segment may appear depressed.

C) CORRECT:

In a person with symptoms consistent with myocardial ischemia, electrocardiographic (ECG) evidence of deep, symmetric T-wave inversions in leads V2 and V3, accompanied by a flat ST segment, is suggestive of a critical stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery. This ECG pattern and associated coronary stenosis is often called Wellens syndrome. Together with the patient’s clinical presentation, the ECG evidence is indicative of unstable angina with high-risk coronary artery disease. Prompt evaluation, including cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, and treatment are warranted.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with dyspnea on exertion and deep, symmetric T-wave inversions in leads V2 and V3 accompanied by a flat ST segment is unstable angina.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with pulmonary embolism, an ECG is most helpful when there is no history of cardiac or pulmonary disease, as the ECG findings are often nonspecific. Although massive acute pulmonary embolism may be associated with negative T waves in the precordial leads in an anterior epicardial ischemic pattern, clinically this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with unstable angina.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation does not suggest aortic dissection. Most patients with aortic dissection present with chest pain, and some have syncope.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is hospitalized at a facility that cannot perform percutaneous coronary intervention receives aspirin, heparin, and intravenous alteplase after presenting with chest pain and electrocardiographic evidence of an evolving anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. Ninety minutes after infusion, his chest pain is unchanged, and an electrocardiogram reveals persistent ST-segment elevation in leads V2 to V6. No accelerated idioventricular rhythm is evident on telemetry. His pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is receiving 2 liters of oxygen by nasal cannula. Examination shows an elevated jugular venous pressure and crackles to the mid-lung fields bilaterally. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Arrange for transfer to a facility that can provide percutaneous coronary intervention
Infuse an additional dose of alteplase

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend thrombolytic therapy for patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) who present within 12 hours after symptom onset when primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) cannot be performed within 2 hours after first medical contact. Criteria for successful thrombolysis include improvement or relief of pain, >50% resolution in the magnitude of ST-segment elevation, and reperfusion arrhythmias (e.g., accelerated idioventricular rhythm).

In patients with persistently occluded infarct-related arteries, urgent transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for rescue PCI (i.e., PCI for failed fibrinolysis) is superior to conservative management, with the benefits greatest in patients with cardiogenic shock, heart failure, or evidence of an extensive area of myocardium at risk (i.e., anterior STEMI).

Key learning point: A patient with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction who has undergone thrombolytic therapy that has apparently failed and who has signs of heart failure should undergo percutaneous coronary intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with the addition of ticagrelor or metoprolol may be a reasonable alternative for a small inferior STEMI, but a patient with a large anterior STEMI should be referred for rescue PCI. In addition, administration of a beta-blocker may exacerbate the heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Tirofiban is indicated for patients undergoing PCI; it is not indicated without concurrent PCI for patients presenting with STEMI.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat fibrinolysis is generally not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat fibrinolysis is generally not recommended.
questions.hint: This patient’s persistent chest pain and ST-segment elevation in the absence of reperfusion arrhythmias strongly suggest a persistently occluded infarct-related artery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman reports a 1-hour history of acute-onset anterior chest pressure associated with shortness of breath. Her pulse is 85/min, blood pressure is 145/78 mm Hg, respirations are 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% while breathing ambient air. Inspiratory crackles extend more than halfway up both lung fields. She has no murmurs, but a third heart sound (S3 gallop) is audible. Her extremities are warm. An electrocardiogram is shown. In addition to aspirin and oxygen, which one of the following combinations of medications should be administered immediately to this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility.

B) CORRECT:

Given that an anterior myocardial infarction is not typically associated with right ventricular involvement, nitroglycerin use is appropriate. Morphine is the drug of choice for pain relief in patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, especially those whose course is complicated by heart failure or pulmonary edema as noted in this case. This drug can alleviate the work of breathing, reduce anxiety, and favorably affect ventricular loading conditions.

Key learning point: The two medication classes that should be avoided in a patient with decompensated heart failure and an acute myocardial infarction are beta-blockers and calcium-channel blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility. Beta-blockers are also contraindicated in patients who have an acute myocardial infarction with advanced (second- or third-degree) atrioventricular block.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility. Beta-blockers are also contraindicated in patients who have an acute myocardial infarction with advanced (second- or third-degree) atrioventricular block.

E) INCORRECT:

An angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, such as lisinopril, is appropriate in this patient with an anterior myocardial infarction, but not in combination with a beta-blocker. Calcium-channel blockers and beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and carvedilol, are contraindicated in patients with myocardial infarction and heart failure, as these drugs may depress myocardial contractility.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man who underwent a total left-hip arthroplasty yesterday reports acute-onset chest pain that began one hour ago. His history is significant for coronary artery disease; and 3 years ago, he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent to his right coronary artery. His inpatient medications after the hip procedure are aspirin, metoprolol tartrate, rosuvastatin, lisinopril, and tamsulosin, as well as hydromorphone as needed. His pulse is 92/min, blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, respirations are16/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on 4 liters of supplemental oxygen. He has a regular rate and rhythm, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, and a short systolic murmur over the left sternal border. An electrocardiogram is shown. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous heparin and CT of the chest according to a pulmonary embolism protocol
Immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography
Metoprolol, heparin, and nitroglycerin — followed by observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may be at increased risk for postoperative pulmonary embolism or acute heart failure, his electrocardiogram findings are diagnostic for myocardial ischemia. Therefore, urgent echocardiography or a pulmonary embolism protocol chest CT scan would not be indicated for this patient. Delays from unnecessary testing may be associated with increased mortality.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads (II, III and aVF) with 2 mm of elevation above the baseline. There is also associated ST depression in leads V2–V4, which are consistent with reciprocal changes. A perioperative ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is a medical emergency that may signal in-stent thrombosis in a patient who has a history of coronary stenting. Urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is an appropriate diagnostic and potentially therapeutic procedure in a perioperative patient with electrocardiographic evidence of STEMI and symptoms of less than 12 hours.

Key learning point: Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction identified in the perioperative setting warrants urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, heparin, and nitroglycerin should be considered for a patient with an acute coronary syndrome but should not delay definitive management of the STEMI with coronary angiography. In addition, in the setting of an inferior myocardial infarction, one should first exclude right ventricular involvement before initiating nitroglycerin.

D) INCORRECT:

Tirofiban and heparin may be appropriate in some patients who are undergoing coronary stenting but are not immediately indicated before urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may be at increased risk for postoperative pulmonary embolism or acute heart failure, his electrocardiogram findings are diagnostic for myocardial ischemia. The electrocardiographic findings of acute pericarditis would be more diffuse than the ST-T abnormalities seen here along a specific vascular territory. Therefore, urgent echocardiography or a pulmonary embolism protocol chest CT scan would not be indicated for this patient. Delays from unnecessary testing may be associated with increased mortality.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department after one hour of dull, substernal chest pain that is associated with nausea, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. Two months ago, she had an ischemic stroke with residual right hemiparesis. Her current medications are losartan and aspirin. On physical examination, she is pale, diaphoretic, and in mild distress. Her pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Her heart rhythm is regular, and she has no murmurs or gallops. Bibasilar crackles are evident. An electrocardiogram is shown. The hospital does not have a cardiac catheterization laboratory. In addition to aspirin, heparin, and initiation of transfer to a facility with a cardiac catheterization laboratory, which one of the following medication regimens is appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase.

B) CORRECT:

The ultimate goal for a patient with an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is timely reperfusion of the infarct-related artery pharmacologically (i.e., with thrombolytic therapy) or mechanically (i.e., with percutaneous coronary intervention [PCI]).

An ischemic stroke within the past 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy because of concern for hemorrhagic conversion and intracranial hemorrhage in this setting. Hence, this patient should not receive reteplase, tenecteplase, or alteplase. Other absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy include previous intracranial hemorrhage, cerebrovascular lesion or intracranial neoplasm, suspected aortic dissection, active bleeding or diatheses, closed-head or facial trauma within the past 3 months, intracranial or intraspinal surgery within the past 2 months, and severe uncontrolled hypertension that is unresponsive to emergency treatment.
